name: 007 First Light
extraInfo: Although 007 First Light isn't launching until 2026, IOI has already confirmed that Pro will still offer both a quality and performance mode. Pro's quality mode will also run at 60fps, utilizing PSSR to achieve this. This suggests that base PS5's quality mode will most likely be limited to 30fps, but this is speculative. It will also be interesting to see whether Pro's performance mode opts for a less resource-intensive upscaler than PSSR, prioritizing other metrics more in line with a framerate-focused mode.

name: 90s Extreme Skiing
extraInfo: Pro features 1.5x supersampling, resulting in a sharper image compared to base PS5. This also virtually eliminates shimmering, which is particularly noticeable in the distance. While the exact resolution and framerate haven't been confirmed, the more basic art style, as well as supersampling now being implemented, suggests it's likely rendering at the PSVR2 panel's highest resolution and refresh rate.

name: Alan Wake 2

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 1224p to 4K PSSR/FSR at a mostly stable 30fps with RT reflections.

modes.name: balanced
modes.description: 864p to 4K PSSR/FSR at a locked 40fps. Combines the RT of the quality mode with image settings of performance. Requires 120 Hz display.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 864p to 4K PSSR/FSR at a mostly stable 60fps (lows of 50fps) with no RT. Graphics settings of base PS5's quality mode (more foliage/better lighting etc).

extraInfo: Pro can toggle between PSSR and FSR for upscaling. FSR is less noisy and more 4K like in stills. PSSR looks sharper in motion with less artifacting. Differences are less obvious in quality mode as base resolution is 1224p (others look relatively soft regardless as 864p to 4K is a big jump). There's no RT on base PS5 and Pro's quality mode also has higher quality shadows, volumetric lighting and fog. All Pro modes have a more stable framerate than their base PS5 equivalent.

name: Alien: Rogue Incursion
extraInfo: Very little is known about the technical performance of the non-VR version of Alien: Rogue Incursion. The only information Survios has provided is via a Gaming Bolt interview, where they said that Pro will have 'greater lighting/volumetric fog fidelity and more realistic reflections and surfacing'. Hopefully, we learn more not too long before the game's September launch.

name: Apex Legends

modes.name: balanced
modes.description: Targets 4K at 60fps with high visual quality. In practice, the fidelity/quality mode.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: Targets 1080p at 120fps with reduced visual quality.

extraInfo: Pro's 2 modes are also on base PS5, but Pro hits the target framerate more often than their base PS5 equivalents. Interestingly, Apex Legends doesn't follow the standard naming convention as there's no fidelity/graphics mode that would have been the 30fps mode in this case.

name: Ark: Survival Ascended
rtTypes: Unreal Engine 5 software-based Lumen reflections and global illumination
extraInfo: Pro has a 30% FPS increase over base PS5 due to its PSSR implementation. While an improvement, base PS5's framerate hovers at around 30-35fps. Therefore, this 30% increase still won't produce a stable 60fps (will hover around 40-45fps, though can sometimes go over with frame gen) and there's no toggle to lock at 30fps/40fps for stability. Pro also uses UE5's virtual shadow maps over base PS5's cascade shadows for long-range and more accurate shadowing.

name: Arken Age

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 4096p per eye at 60fps re-projected to 120fps.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 2240p per eye at 90fps native (no-reprojection).

extraInfo: VitruviusVR recommend Pro's performance mode in the settings menu, likely due to the native motion. Base PS5's resolutions are 2432p in quality mode and 2048p in performance mode (framerates remain the same).

name: Arma Reforger

modes.name: fidelity
modes.description: 1944p to 4K FSR 1 at a nearly locked 30fps. Better ambient occlusion and cloud quality compared to performance mode.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1440p to 4K FSR 1 at a relatively unstable 60fps. Doesn't have fidelity mode's shadows on terrain surfaces/contact shadows.

extraInfo: Base PS5 is exactly the same, but at 1620p and 1080p respectively. Performance mode has a decent amount of screen tearing. You can add an FPS counter to the HUD.

name: Asphalt Legends Unite

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 4K native at up to 120fps. Usually around 90fps with VRR during racing.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: DRS that reaches up to native 4K at a locked 120fps.

extraInfo: Pro performance mode's dynamic resolution scaling doesn't dip very far from 4K in order to maintain 120fps. It's near-impossible to tell a difference from normal viewing distances unless looking at the modes side-by-side.

name: Assassin's Creed Mirage
extraInfo: Through PSSR, Pro combines the 4K resolution, better shadows/reflections, higher texture resolution, and improved draw distance seen in the base PS5's 30fps quality mode, with the 60fps seen in base PS5's performance mode. Pro's framerate is also a nearly locked 60fps and more stable than base PS5's performance mode.

name: Assassin's Creed Shadows
rtTypes: Ray traced global illumination and reflections

modes.name: quality
modes.description: Around 1584p-1656p DRS to 4K TAAU/PSSR at a basically locked 30fps. Has both RT reflections and RTGI throughout open world. Higher quality draw distances, foliage density, shadows, textures, hair quality etc than performance mode.

modes.name: balanced
modes.description: Around 1440p DRS to 4K TAAU/PSSR at a stable 40fps with RT reflections (PSSR only) and RTGI (both upscalers). Graphical settings straddle between quality and performance modes (shadows of performance mode, hair strands of quality mode etc).

modes.name: performance
modes.description: Around 1080p DRS to 4K TAAU/PSSR at a stable 60fps (lows of low 50s). No RT reflections, but RTGI remains throughout the world.

extraInfo: You can toggle between PSSR and TAAU as the upscaler. PSSR is a little softer, but much more stable with less aliasing/shimmer. TAAU's foliage/SSR is especially grainy and all of these issues are exacerbated in motion. PSSR fails to hit target framerate in performance mode as often (usually around 4-8fps fewer when it does drop), but still remains in the VRR window. RTGI is far more important to image quality than RT reflections. Base PS5's performance mode only has RTGI in the hideout, making Pro's performance mode a generational leap due to the improved lighting across the map. There's also no RT reflections on base PS5.

name: Astro Bot
extraInfo: Pro runs at 1368p-1872p DRS to 4K PSSR, with a locked 60fps, and is more often in the higher bounds of the DRS. Despite Pro's DRS having a lower base resolution than base PS5, Pro's PSSR upscaling is cleaner/sharper with less aliasing compared to base PS5's TAA. PSSR is however slightly noisier (especially SSR) and more unstable, but this isn't particularly visible at normal viewing distances.

name: Atomfall
extraInfo: Pro has DRS but can render at native 4K with a locked 60fps, whereas base PS5 renders a maximum of 1800p and has a less stable framerate. However, both can dip to 1440p and neither hit their top resolution most of the time. All versions are also poorly aliased (even PC), so resolution differences are less noticeable compared to other games because there's so much shimmer/jaggies regardless. There's also low resolution surfaces and very poor SSR (equivalent to PC low settings) that exacerbate the shimmer. Finally, the overkill AO (including the RT) overly silhouettes the image (especially characters) on all consoles and can't be turned off.

name: Avatar: Pandora Frontiers
rtTypes: Ray traced reflections and global illumination

modes.name: quality pro
modes.description: 900p-1152p DRS to 4K PSSR/FSR at a mostly stable 60fps.

modes.name: quality
modes.description: Sharper than quality pro (1512p-1800p DRS to 4K PSSR/FSR) but at a locked 30fps.

modes.name: balanced
modes.description: Visual quality downgraded compared to quality but now at a locked 40fps.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: Lowest visual quality. Usually 936p DRS to 4K PSSR/FSR at a nearly locked 60fps, compared to base PS5's 720p DRS to 4K FSR with a less stable 60fps.

extraInfo: All modes can use either PSSR or FSR3 for upscaling to 4K. FSR is less noisy/unstable and looks sharper in stills, however PSSR is both sharper and clearer in motion (where most of the gameplay will be). PSSR works best with the quality 30fps mode due to its highest internal DRS. Quality/balanced/performance are all the legacy modes from base PS5, but will run at the higher DRS bounds (1800p for quality etc) more often due to Pro's extra power.

name: Baldur's Gate 3

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 4K native at a nearly locked 30fps.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1440p to 4K PSSR at a mostly stable 60fps.

extraInfo: Pro's performance mode looks better than even base PS5's quality mode due to upscalers used. PSSR is a little bit softer than base PS5's FSR, but much more stable with less artifacting/flickering. This instability is especially noticeable with assets in motion, such as moving shadows. Pro also has an approx 10% higher framerate, so manages to reach 60fps more often than base PS5. Finally, Pro can also run split screen at either 30fps or 60fps, compared to just 30fps on base PS5.

name: Battlefield 6
extraInfo: Battlefield Studios has confirmed that there will be a quality and performance mode on even base PS5, with 'visual performance enhancements' for Pro. As Battlefield has targeted at least 60fps on PlayStation since PS4, it's likely that quality mode will run at 60fps, with Pro having improved graphical settings and/or resolution over base PS5. Furthermore, as Battlefield 2042 was the first game in the series to support 120fps on a PlayStation, 120fps is likely the target for the performance mode, with Pro probably just having a higher internal resolution over the base PS5. Finally, it's likely neither mode has RT as even on PC, there has only been limited support. What these modes entail is however just educated guesses base off the history of the IP on PlayStation and we won't know for sure until closer to launch.

name: Beneath
extraInfo: Camel 101 have confirmed that they're targeting 4K and 60fps on both base PS5 and Pro. They've also confirmed that Pro will utilize PSSR for 'enhanced visuals'. This potentially means that PSSR is doing a better job of creating a 4K-like image than base PS5's upscaler, or could simply mean that PSSR is using a higher internal resolution than what's on base PS5 due to Pro's extra power. We'll find out closer to the game's late 2025 launch.

name: Biped
extraInfo: Biped has no display options, so features like an 120fps mode aren't available. However, Pro at least maintains a locked 60fps. Pro also renders a 1440p image compared to base PS5's more 1080p-like image. The resolution difference can be quite noticeable on assets like railings, where there's more jaggies on base PS5.

name: Biped 2
extraInfo: *Biped 2 isn't out until Q3 2025 (potentially September 30), but the following Biped 1 information provides a good baseline of what to expect - 'Biped has no display options, so features like an 120fps mode aren't available. However, Pro at least maintains a locked 60fps. Pro also renders a 1440p image compared to base PS5's more 1080p-like image. The resolution difference can be quite noticeable on assets like railings, where there's more jaggies on base PS5.'

name: Black Desert

modes.name: fidelity
modes.description: 4K at a mostly locked 60fps.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1080p at a locked 60fps.

extraInfo: Black Desert (likely) doesn't have Pro enhancements yet despite confirmation that Pearl Abyss are working on it. At the very least, the fidelity mode's 60fps will be more stable on Pro due to the extra horsepower. However, both modes suffer from severe pop in that includes texture quality and actual assets. This makes the image rather poor regardless of mode and can't be fixed on console.

name: Black Myth: Wukong
rtTypes: Unreal Engine 5 Lumen software-based global illumination

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 1296p to 4K PSSR at a very stable 30fps.

modes.name: balanced
modes.description: 1296p to 4K PSSR at a very stable 40fps on 120 Hz screens or 45fps on 60 Hz. Lower resolution shadows than quality mode.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1080p to 1440p FSR3. Frame-gen used to target a still unstable 60ps.

extraInfo: Base PS5's performance mode is very similar to Pro and also uses frame generation. However due to frame gen, the quality/balanced modes have less input lag and therefore feel more responsive despite fewer frames. Pro's PSSR in these modes also offer a far clearer image (albeit a little noisier) than FSR3 and FSR2, which base PS5 uses in its balanced and quality modes to target an upscaled 1440p.

name: Blades Of Fire
extraInfo: Both PS5 consoles cap the framerate at 60fps. On Pro, there's dynamic resolution scaling that ranges from 1080p-4K native before being upscaled to 4K PSSR. With 1080p being the lowest internal resolution value, PSSR is still able to reconstruct an excellent 4K image in the most demanding areas.

name: Borderlands 4
extraInfo: Randy Pitchford has stated that B4 is targeting 60fps on all consoles. Based on B3's and TTW's quality modes on base PS5, B4 would presumably render at native 4K - though this hasn't been confirmed. B3/TTW also featured a 120fps performance mode, which will hopefully carry over to B4. However, B3 was originally a PS4 title, and its PS5 update could drop below 1080p to hit 120fps. Since B4 is a current-gen only game, 120fps might not be possible without the internal resolution falling to an unacceptable level. In any case, 120fps remains speculative, and we won't know for sure until closer to B4's launch.

name: Call Of Duty: Black Ops 6

modes.name: fidelity
modes.description: 1440p to 4K PSSR at a mostly locked 60fps, or typically around 70-90fps with VRR. Improved global illumination (biggest improvement), ambient occlusion, reflections and 2-4x shadow resolution compared to 120 Hz mode.

modes.name: 120 Hz refresh rate
modes.description: 1440p to 4K TAA at a relatively stable 120fps. Graphics settings the same as base PS5's fidelity mode that runs at 60fps.

extraInfo: The anti-lag VRR implementation in Pro's fidelity mode (120 Hz refresh rate toggled off) means it actually has lower input latency than the 120 Hz mode, despite fewer frames. An improved PSSR implementation also arrived in a patch that significantly reduced artifacting/white dots in some areas, although they're still somewhat visible on rare occasions. Splitscreen multiplayer is now a locked 60fps (mid 50s on base PS5).

name: Chess Infinity
rtTypes: Unreal Engine 5 Lumen hardware-based lighting, reflections and shadows

modes.name: fidelity
modes.description: 1440p-4K native DRS at a mostly locked 30fps with all RT.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1080p-1440p DRS to 4K TSR at a mostly locked 60fps with all RT.

extraInfo: Pro uses superior hardware-based RT compared to software-based RT on base PS5 (less breakup/clearer reflections etc). Performance can dip depending on scene complexity, which will then kick in the dynamic resolution scaling.

name: Clair Obscur: Expedition 33
rtTypes: Unreal Engine 5 Lumen software-based global illumination/reflections and Nanite virtual shadow maps with RT

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 1080p-1552p DRS to 4K TSR at a locked 30fps. Both software-based Lumen GI and reflections, as well as RT shadows via Nanite (though not all shadows receive RT for accurate diffuse).

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1062p-1386p DRS to 1800p TSR at a nearly locked 60fps. Lower quality Lumen GI/reflections compared to quality mode and no RT shadows.

extraInfo: Quality mode has a noticeably sharper image with less shimmer/breakup in hair. Performance mode can dip below 60fps, but stays well within the VRR window and only lasts a couple seconds. Base PS5 also has DRS and its internal resolution can go as low as 720p (performance) and 900p (quality), leading to far more shimmer/breakup. Real-time cutscenes are an uneven 30fps regardless of mode or hardware (even PC) and the early FMV cutscenes have visible macroblocking.

name: Crystal Of Atlan
extraInfo: Nuverse has confirmed that Pro uses PSSR to upscale to a 4K image. This isn't possible on base PS5 as PSSR is an AI upscaler.

name: CyubeVR
resolution: 8K textures with dynamic foveated rendering for the rest of the image
extraInfo: Pro has increased distance for maximum LOD quality of the landscape and anything the player has built on it. Pro also has higher LOD quality for trees so changes are less noticeable from a distance.

name: Days Gone Remastered

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 2880p (5K) at a locked 30fps or around 35fps with VRR. Supersamples down to 2160p (4K) on 4K displays for the sharpest image of any mode on any console.

modes.name: enhanced
modes.description: 1584p to 4K PSSR at a nearly locked 60fps or around 70fps with VRR. As sharp as the native PS4 app playing on PS5 with no checkerboard rendering artifacts.

modes.name: balanced
modes.description: 4K PSSR at a locked 40fps, or around 55fps with VRR. PSSR used for aliasing, not upscaling. Sharper than enhanced mode but less sharp than quality mode.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1800p to 4K at a nearly locked 60fps, or around 65fps with VRR. Slightly blurrier than PS4 app on PS5, but has higher detailed LODs/no CBR artifacts.

extraInfo: Compared to PS4, the biggest upgrade is the new sky simulation, which renders more accurate sunlight and darker nights. There's also increased foliage/draw distance (past PC max settings), as well as higher resolution shadows/textures, improved SSR/SSGI and more vibrant general lighting (sub-surface scattering/key lights). PSSR in enhanced mode is noisier in distant assets and foliage can blur when swaying, but looks much better in motion. VRR can be used in all modes and gives Pro's balanced mode the most significant advantage over its base PS5 equivalent. Base PS5 performance mode is so blurry that it looks worse than even the native PS4 app.

name: Dead Island 2
extraInfo: The framerate is a locked 60fps on both consoles, but Pro improves shadow quality, motion blur, texture filtering and depth of field over base PS5. Pro also has longer draw distances and contact shadows on all objects/lights. Pro uses DRS, but the resolution is above 2000p for the majority of gameplay, including often at native 4K. It can drop down as low as 1620p (technically lower than base PS5's fixed 1728p), but this is very rare and only lasts a couple of seconds.

name: Dead Rising Deluxe
extraInfo: Pro uses RT reflections, which are a huge improvement over base PS5's screen space reflections due to the shopping mall setting (storefront windows etc). While both base PS5 and Pro run at native 4K, Pro also has a locked 60fps even with RT reflections, whereas base PS5 dips into the low 50s in the most demanding scenarios. This is most likely why base PS5 doesn't support RT.

name: Death Stranding 2: OTB

modes.name: prioritize quality
modes.description: 4K native at a locked 30fps.

modes.name: prioritize performance
modes.description: 1440p-4K DRS at a very nearly locked 60fps.

extraInfo: Pro's performance and quality modes look nearly identical despite a 2x in framerate. Both Pro and base PS5 performance modes run in an 120 Hz container, resulting in less input lag. Outside of base PS5's higher DRS (1800p-4K) in quality mode, Pro performance mode matches its graphical settings (distant terrain detail/geometry, shadows, AO & texture LODs). Base PS5 performance mode's 1260p-1800p DRS can be noticeably blurrier, with more image instability/shimmer/fizzle as well as worse reflections/shadows/draw distance than all the other modes.

name: Demon's Souls

modes.name: PS5 pro
modes.description: 1440p-1584p DRS to 4K PSSR with improved shadows at a locked 60fps.

modes.name: cinematic
modes.description: Legacy base PS5 mode. 4K native at a locked 30fps.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: Legacy base PS5 mode. 1440p at a locked 60fps.

extraInfo: While the native 4K in base PS5's cinematic (quality) mode is a little sharper than PS5 Pro mode, it's also far more noisy, more aliased, and less temporally stable than the 1440p-1584p DRS to 4K PSSR in the Pro mode, which therefore has the better image quality despite the lower internal resolution. PS5 Pro mode also has improved shadows and a locked 60fps, therefore making the legacy cinematic/performance modes redundant.

name: Diablo IV

modes.name: enhanced visuals
modes.description: DRS that reaches up to 4K native at 30fps. RT shadows and reflections. Improves quality of fur, hair and fog compared to performance mode.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: Upscaled 4K at 60fps. No RT.

extraInfo: Enhanced visuals mode hovers around 45-50fps with VRR. It therefore won't always prevent stutter as the framerate can dip below the 48fps VRR threshold on PlayStation. Fortunately, Pro's enhanced visuals mode still has a higher resolution, improved ambient occlusion and higher quality RT reflections compared base PS5's equivalent mode.

name: Doom: The Dark Ages
extraInfo: Pro drops frames in more demanding open arenas, but stays within the VRR window (mid 50s) and is still generally more stable than base PS5. Base PS5 renders between 1008p-1440p DRS (usually around 1080p) compared to the 1260p-1800p DRS (usually around 1620p) on Pro. With Pro's lower bounds only being in these more open arenas. RTGI quality is the same on both, but Pro has a slightly better draw distance and anisotropic filtering. Variable rate shading is used on every console (Xbox too), resulting in a blurrier image than the resolution would suggest. VRS is therefore least noticeable on Pro. Finally, RT reflections and path tracing are PC only.

name: Dragon Age: The Veilguard

modes.name: fidelity
modes.description: Roughly 1296p to 4K PSSR at a nearly locked 30fps with RTAO.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: Roughly 864p-1296p DRS to 1800p PSSR at a nearly locked 60fps with RTAO. Can flicker a lot/look very aliased due to low base resolution.

extraInfo: Base PS5 uses FSR instead of PSSR, where it's 1080p to 1800p FSR (fidelity) and 864p to 1440p FSR (performance). Base PS5 is a lot softer, but less flickering/aliasing can make foliage/reflections look better compared to Pro. You can see the differences in the background of the menu when toggling between the modes (AO on foliage etc).

name: Dragon's Dogma 2

modes.name: prioritize graphics
modes.description: 1440p to 4K PSSR at an unevenly paced 30fps. Around 40-50fps with VRR.

modes.name: balanced
modes.description: 1080p to 4K PSSR at a relatively locked 60fps (lows of low 50s).

modes.name: prioritize performance
modes.description: 720p to 4K PSSR at a mostly locked 60fps. Usually around 70-85fps with VRR.

extraInfo: All modes can toggle RTGI on/off. When enabled, the framerate is around 10fps fewer than the values stated above. Due to PSSR, RT is noisy/aliased and looks worse as the internal resolution lowers in subsequent modes. This exacerbation is also true with regular occlusion, although PSSR still creates a sharper image and significantly improves ghosting, texture detail and material quality compared to FSR on base PS5. Pro also hits its target framerate much more often than base PS5 in all modes.

name: Dreams Of Another
extraInfo: Q-Games has only briefly mentioned the Pro enhancements. For example, Pro will have 'detailed point cloud visuals'. They've also brought up resolution numerous times, which combined with the more artistic graphics, makes it likely that Pro can render DoA at PSVR2's maximum resolution/framerate. This is pure speculation however and we won't know for sure until closer to launch.

name: Dying Light 2: Stay Human
rtTypes: Ray traced shadows, reflections and ambient occlusion

modes.name: resolution
modes.description: Native 4K at a locked 30 FPS with no RT. Better contact shadows compared to base PS5.

modes.name: quality
modes.description: Upscaled 4K at a locked 30 FPS with RT. Now with increased base resolution (1440p) and better contact shadows compared to base PS5.

modes.name: balanced
modes.description: Upscaled 4K at nearly locked 60 FPS with no RT. Increased base resolution (1512p) compared to base PS5.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: Upscaled 4K with no RT and with VRR, up to 120 FPS. Increased base resolution (1440p), better contact shadows, spot shadows, and fog quality compared to base PS5.

extraInfo: All of Pro's modes also have improved global illumination, screen space reflections (except quality mode due to RT) and sub surface scattering compared to their equivalent base PS5 mode.

name: Dying Light: The Beast
rtTypes: Ray traced shadows, reflections and ambient occlusion

modes.name: resolution
modes.description: Native 4K at a locked 30 FPS with no RT. Better contact shadows compared to base PS5.

modes.name: quality
modes.description: Upscaled 4K at a locked 30 FPS with RT. Now with increased base resolution (1440p) and better contact shadows compared to base PS5.

modes.name: balanced
modes.description: Upscaled 4K at nearly locked 60 FPS with no RT. Increased base resolution (1512p) compared to base PS5.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: Upscaled 4K with no RT and with VRR, up to 120 FPS. Increased base resolution (1440p), better contact shadows, spot shadows, and fog quality compared to base PS5.

extraInfo: 'All of Pro's modes also have improved global illumination, screen space reflections (except quality mode due to RT) and sub surface scattering compared to their equivalent base PS5 mode.' - The aforementioned modes/extra information is taken from Dying Light 2, as DL: The Beast has no hard technical figures just yet. However, Techland have publicly stated that The Beast will take its modes much further than DL2: SH. So we should expect that what's above provides a good baseline of what to expect.

name: Dynasty Warriors: Origins

modes.name: native 4K
modes.description: 4K at a very unstable 60fps (dips into low 50s, which is in VRR window).

modes.name: prioritize graphics
modes.description: 1512p-4K DRS at a nearly locked 60fps (can dip into high 50s, which is comfortably in VRR window).

modes.name: prioritize framerate
modes.description: 1440p at a locked 60fps.

extraInfo: Prioritize graphics mode's DRS averages around 1700p during actual gameplay and the framerate can dip into high 50s. Native 4K mode barely hits 60fps, but at least stays within the VRR window as it's usually around the low 50s during combat.

name: EA College Football 25
rtTypes: GIBS (EA's own global illumination - hardware ray tracing for indirect lighting)
extraInfo: Pro removes the resolution, performance and visual quality modes on base PS5 for just one mode. Pro's PSSR renders a sharper image than even base PS5's resolution mode and there's now 3D grass in gameplay, on more zoomed in cameras. However, PSSR also causes assets like crowd handrails to be more unstable. Pro's cutscenes/instant replays are now 60fps like in base PS5's performance mode and gameplay is a locked 60fps. Finally, the GIBS RT implementation seems unchanged.

name: EA College Football 26
rtTypes: GIBS (EA's own global illumination - hardware ray tracing for indirect lighting)
extraInfo: CFB 26 on Pro provides the same upgrades over base PS5 that CFB 25 had. Pro removes the resolution, performance and visual quality modes on base PS5 for just one mode. Pro's PSSR renders a sharper image than even base PS5's resolution mode and there's now 3D grass in gameplay, on more zoomed in cameras. However, PSSR also causes assets like crowd handrails to be more unstable. Pro's cutscenes/instant replays are now 60fps like in base PS5's performance mode and gameplay is a locked 60fps. Finally, the GIBS RT implementation seems unchanged.

name: EA Sports FC 25
extraInfo: Pro combines base PS5's 'resolution' and 'enhanced visuals' modes into just one default mode. Pro sometimes renders an even sharper image than base PS5's resolution mode, while maintaining enhanced visuals mode's RTAO on pitch lighting/kits etc. Pro's cutscenes are now also 60fps, as opposed to 30fps on base PS5.

name: EA Sports FC 26
extraInfo: *FC 26 isn't out yet, but the following information from last year's FC 25 provides a good baseline of what to expect - 'Pro combines base PS5's 'resolution' and 'enhanced visuals' modes into just one default mode. Pro sometimes renders an even sharper image than base PS5's resolution mode, while maintaining enhanced visuals mode's RTAO on pitch lighting/kits etc. Pro's cutscenes are now also 60fps, as opposed to 30fps on base PS5.'

name: EA Sports UFC 5
extraInfo: Pro's resolution during gameplay is slightly higher than base PS5. Pro also renders KO replays at 60fps instead of base PS5's 30fps. However, other cutscenes like ring entrances remain at 30fps on both consoles.

name: Empire Of The Ants
extraInfo: Base PS5 uses dynamic resolution scaling, which can have a higher internal resolution than Pro as it ranges from 1400p-1600p to 4K TSR, but only runs at 30fps compared to Pro's locked 60fps. Pro's fixed internal resolution of 1440p is also high enough that there's barely a difference between consoles once UE5's TSR is implemented.

name: Enlisted

modes.name: high quality
modes.description: 1920p to 4K PSSR at a basically locked 60fps.

modes.name: high performance
modes.description: 1620p to 4K PSSR at a stable 120fps.

extraInfo: Pro's high performance mode now hits a solid 120fps, whereas base PS5's version is usually around 90fps with a lower 1440p internal resolution. Pro also has higher quality shadows, improved Global Illumination and due to PSSR, the overall image quality/clarity has improved.

name: Everspace 2
extraInfo: Despite Everspace 2 being one of the earliest games to be mentioned for Pro support, it still isn't Pro enhanced as of August 2025. The last update came in early 2025, when Rockfish told a Redditor that they were still trying to acquire a PS5 Pro dev kit. These were quite rare at the time, so Rockfish couldn't provide a timeframe for a patch. Hopefully, this situation changes soon and Everspace 2 receives its Pro enhancements before 2026.

name: F1 24
rtTypes: Ray traced dynamic diffuse global illumination, ambient occlusion, shadows and reflections

modes.name: 8K
modes.description: 4K to 8K TAAU at a locked 30fps. Gameplay has all RT, including shadows. Requires an 8K TV as it can't be down-sampled.

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 1080p-1440p DRS to 4K PSSR. A locked 60fps with all RT in gameplay except shadows.

modes.name: 120 Hz performance
modes.description: 1080p-1440p DRS to 4K TAAU. Mostly at a locked 120fps with no RT.

extraInfo: Base PS5's quality mode has no RT during gameplay, whereas Pro's quality mode has 3/4 RT which dramatically improves realism. Pro even brings back RT shadows for cutscenes (which are now at 40fps, instead of base PS5's 30fps) and replays. Base PS5's quality mode resolution is 1800p-4K DRS, yet Pro's PSSR very nearly matches its sharpness despite being at 1080p-1440p DRS. Base PS5 has no 8K mode and its 120 Hz performance mode is also usually at 1080p compared to Pro's 1440p.

name: F1 25
rtTypes: Ray traced dynamic diffuse global illumination, ambient occlusion, shadows and reflections

modes.name: resolution
modes.description: 4K to 8K TAAU at a locked 60fps with only RT DDGI in gameplay. Cutscenes/replays have all RT, but at 40fps. Requires an 8K TV as it can't be down-sampled.

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 1080p-1440p DRS to 4K PSSR. A locked 60fps with all RT in gameplay except shadows.

modes.name: 120 Hz performance
modes.description: 1080p-1440p DRS to 4K TAAU. Mostly at a locked 120fps with no RT.

extraInfo: *The biggest change from F1 24 to F1 25 is the 8K resolution mode. Whereas F1 24's gameplay included all RT, but ran at 8K/30fps, F1 25 only includes DDGI, but runs at 60fps whilst keeping 24's version for cutscenes/replays etc. Otherwise, the rest of the F1 24 info remains true - 'Base PS5's quality mode has no RT during gameplay, whereas Pro's quality mode has 3/4 RT which dramatically improves realism. Pro even brings back RT shadows for cutscenes (which are now at 40fps, instead of base PS5's 30fps) and replays. Base PS5's quality mode resolution is 1800p-4K DRS, yet Pro's PSSR very nearly matches its sharpness despite being at 1080p-1440p DRS. Base PS5 has no 8K mode and its 120 Hz performance mode is also usually at 1080p compared to Pro's 1440p.'

name: Faaast Penguin
extraInfo: The only display setting is a brightness slider. However, Pro has a locked framerate that runs within an 120 Hz container to improve input lag (base PS5 is only at at 60 Hz). Pro could potentially render below native 4K sometimes, but it would only be for a very short duration, with dips would be so minor that FP still has a 4K-like image.

name: Farming Simulator 25
extraInfo: Whereas base PS5 has a quality (1600p to 4K at 30fps) and performance 60fps mode, Pro just has a singular mode that runs at a native 4K at a basically locked 60fps.

name: FBC: Firebreak
extraInfo: Unlike Alan Wake 2, which offered a graphics, balanced and performance mode, FBC only has one mode that's 4K at a mostly locked 60fps with no RT. The only toggle on Pro is whether you want to use PSSR or FSR2 as your upscaler to 4K. This isn't an option on base PS5 (which uses FSR2 to upscale to 1440p) as it can't use PSSR.

name: Final Fantasy VII Rebirth

modes.name: versatility
modes.description: 1224p-1440 DRS to 4K PSSR at a very stable 60fps.

modes.name: graphics
modes.description: Legacy base PS5 mode. 1880p-4K native DRS at a locked 30fps.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: Legacy base PS5 performance mode(s), with a sharp or smooth variation. 1152p-1440p DRS at a stable 60fps.

extraInfo: Pro's new versatility mode runs at 1224p-1440p DRS to 4K PSSR at a very stable 60fps. All base PS5 modes are present and its 30fps graphics mode can have a much higher internal resolution. However Pro's PSSR implementation, though a bit noisier/unstable, still creates a far sharper image (especially distant detail) than graphics mode, with better SSR and less ghosting/artifacting, and at 60fps. Considering versatility mode has both the clearest image and highest/most stable framerate (its 60fps is more stable than the performance mode), all other modes are redundant.

name: Fortnite
rtTypes: Hardware-based ray traced reflections, shadows and global illumination

modes.name: fidelity
modes.description: 1350p to 4K TSR at a near locked 60fps with hardware-based RT reflections, shadows & global illumination.

modes.name: 120fps performance
modes.description: 1080p to 4K TSR at a basically locked 120fps, but with no RT.

extraInfo: Pro's performance mode looks practically identical to base PS5's performance mode. Base PS5's fidelity mode only uses software-based RT, meaning Pro has better RT implementation due to being hardware-based (less breakup/shimmering/pop-in, more detailed/stable assets, character models in reflections, more accurate indirect lighting).

name: Forza Horizon 5

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 4K at a locked 30fps. RT reflections on player car in races and free roam gameplay.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 4K at a locked 60fps. Same graphical settings as quality mode, but with no RT reflections.

extraInfo: Graphics in Pro's performance mode are equivalent to base PS5's quality mode, but at a locked 60fps instead of 30fps. Base PS5's performance mode is a big step down from all others. It has far less foliage onscreen, more pop-in, and can render under 4K (DRS hovers around 1728p-1872p when it drops) for a few seconds. RT on Pro is nice, but only affects certain assets (only player car, not other racers etc) and is hard to notice in general gameplay. Cutscenes are 30fps regardless of mode or console.

name: Gears Of War: Reloaded

modes.name: 60 Hz
modes.description: 1440p-1800p DRS to 4K at a locked 60fps.

modes.name: 120 Hz
modes.description: 1440p-1607p DRS to 4K at a locked 120fps.

extraInfo: Base PS5's 60 HZ mode has the same lowest base resolution of 1440p, but only goes up to 1552p. Base PS5's internal resolution in 120 HZ mode only goes up to 1080p compared to 1607p on Pro and can drop to 914p. Please note, this information is taken from the multiplayer beta and is likely to be a little different in the final version. The PSN store also confirms PSSR and improved shadow/reflections quality, so we'll see how these implementations fare too in late August.

name: Ghost Of Yōtei
extraInfo: *The following technical information is based off Digital Foundry's analysis of various Ghost Of Yōtei and Tsushima trailers. It's therefore all subject to change, but gives us a good baseline of what to expect - 'Facial animations of main characters look vastly improved over GoT, with more subtlety and detail. GoY is running at 4K/30fps in trailers, but there's no form of RT. It therefore looks worse when compared to similar games such as AC: Shadows. Shadow resolution does however seems to be much higher compared to GoT. There's no official confirmation of a performance mode or VRR to push past 60fps, but it's likely given Sucker Punch's past work on PS5.'

name: God Of War: Ragnarök
rtTypes: Very light ray traced reflections for scene-aligned cube maps

modes.name: PS5 pro enhanced
modes.description: Graphical settings of favor quality mode (RT, better shadows/ambient occlusion/textures & longer draw distance than HFR mode), but runs at 60fps.

modes.name: high frame rate
modes.description: Unlocks framerate for up to 120fps (often around 70-105fps depending on upscaler) on VRR displays.

modes.name: Favor Quality
modes.description: Legacy base PS5 quality mode capped at 30fps. Now redundant.

modes.name: Favor Performance
modes.description: Legacy base PS5 performance mode capped at 60fps. Now redundant.

extraInfo: Pro can toggle between TAA and PSSR for upscaling. PSSR is sharper and clearer (especially distant assets) with less fizzle in motion, but less stable with around 10-20fps fewer in HFR mode. Both upscalers use 1440p as the base resolution but PS5 Pro Enhanced mode can regularly have an internal resolution of around 1800p. No need to bother with the legacy base PS5 modes as there are no advantages to do so.

name: Gran Turismo 7

modes.name: 8K 60 Hz
modes.description: 4K to 8K PSSR at a locked 60fps, but with no RT. Requires PSSR to upscale.

modes.name: prioritize ray-tracing/resolution
modes.description: 4K PSSR/TAA at a locked 60fps with RT reflections.

modes.name: prioritize framerate
modes.description: 1800p to 4K PSSR/TAA at a locked 120fps with no RT.

extraInfo: Unlike base PS5, RT reflections are now available during gameplay. Its excellent implementation is far superior to the cube maps used when RT is disabled. Both TAA and PSSR are available for upscaling and both support RT except for cockpit mode, which is only PSSR. PSSR still looks great, but can can produce additional shimmer/noise in thin objects and artifacting on a few cars compared to TAA. All framerates are locked 99% of the time in gameplay, but replays can drop the framerate more often. Finally, Pro significantly improves motion clarity and image quality in its optional PSVR2 mode.

name: Grand Theft Auto 6
rtTypes: Ray traced global illumination and reflections
extraInfo: *GTA 6 isn't confirmed to be Pro enhanced yet, but considering its budget, IP legacy, how Rockstar Games are perfectionists, and that it's currently the most anticipated game, it's the one game worth fully speculating. All info is from DF's analysis of the second trailer which was real-time on base PS5, making it a good baseline of what to expect on Pro. GTA 6's resolution was 1440p. There's diffuse RTGI for direct/indirect lighting and it's more stable compared to software UE5 Lumen that's popular on consoles. There's RT reflections that includes dynamic objects like people, even on rough/opaque surfaces (water etc), but SSR is still sometimes used in combination. RT reflections on transparent surfaces (glass) is top-tier. There's no RT shadows, but still looks great with accurate diffuse. The trailer's most impressive aspect is the accurate/natural hair rendering, regardless of hairstyle and even body hair. Finally, even on Pro, a 60fps mode is unlikely, but 40fps could be possible.

name: Hellblade 1
extraInfo: Hellblade was re-released on Series X in 2021 and had 3 modes - a 4K/30fps with RT reflections mode, a 4K/60fps with no RT mode, and a 1080p/nearly locked 120fps mode. Based on this release, it's likely that base PS5 will have almost identical modes. For Pro, its extra power could lead to a 4K/30fps mode with additional RT features like AO, a 4K/60fps mode but with RT as well, and a more locked 120fps mode but at 1440p. This is just an educated guess however and we won't know until closer to Hellblade's PS5 launch.

name: Hellblade 2: Senua's Saga
rtTypes: Unreal Engine 5 Lumen reflections (hopefully hardware-based, but at least software-based)
extraInfo: Hellblade II launched on Xbox last year, but was limited to 30fps, at 1440p to 4K TSR, with software-based RT. It's already been confirmed that H2 will now include a 60fps mode that has a lower resolution and worse graphical settings, but won't strip out features like RT. This mode will be on Series X/base PS5, meaning it's also there on Pro. But while Pro could probably render at native 4K, it'll likely keep Series X's 1440p for its 60fps mode due to H2's extensive use of post-processing, which minimizes the impact of a base resolution increase. Hopefully instead, Pro incorporates superior hardware-accelerated RT that would be exclusive to Pro/PC, but this is just optimistic speculation. Ninja Theory have also confirmed that Pro can use either PSSR or UE5's TSR as the upscaler, so it will be interesting to see which performs better especially as PSSR isn't possible on base PS5.

name: Helldivers 2

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 4K at an improperly paced, but stable 30fps.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1440p at a mostly stable 60fps (drops to 50s with explosions etc).

extraInfo: Pro sees resolution increases in both modes as on base PS5, quality mode is 1728p and performance is 1080p. However, both consoles render a relatively unstable image due to mediocre TAA, regardless of mode. There's therefore a larger gap between performance modes, with less shimmering/clearer text on Pro. Pro's 60fps is more stable than base PS5, with only the hardest difficulties causing 5-10fps drops (still within VRR). Both quality modes are improperly paced, but Pro is more stable.

name: Hitman Trilogy
extraInfo: Pro is a locked 60fps at 4K native, compared to the 1800p mostly stable 60fps on base PS5. Essentially, putting Pro on par with the Series X version.

name: Hogwarts Legacy

modes.name: fidelity ray-tracing
modes.description: 1728p to 4K PSSR at nearly locked 30fps with RT reflections and shadows.

modes.name: fidelity
modes.description: 1728p to 4K PSSR at locked 30fps without RT.

modes.name: balanced
modes.description: Only for 120 Hz screens. 4K PSSR at nearly locked 40fps without RT.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1440p to 4K PSSR at nearly locked 60fps without RT.

modes.name: high frame rate
modes.description: Only for 120 Hz/VRR screens. Can drop to 1080p as base resolution and no framerate cap. Usually around 80fps without RT.

extraInfo: You can remove the framerate cap in the fidelity and balanced modes, increasing the framerate by 5-10fps. RT shadows are better quality than base PS5, but less accurate on some moving objects. RT reflections have twice the resolution on Pro compared to base PS5. It also applies to bodies of water unlike base PS5 which uses SSR, though can look noisy due to PSSR. Pro performance modes have same graphical settings as the other Pro modes outside of RT. Base PS5 uses FSR 1 to upscale, which looks sharper, but more aliased than PSSR.

name: Horizon 1 Zero Dawn

modes.name: favor resolution pro
modes.description: 1584p-4K native DRS at a locked 30fps.

modes.name: balanced pro
modes.description: Looks almost identical to favor performance pro mode, but is capped at 40fps.

modes.name: favor performance pro
modes.description: 1440p-1584p DRS to 4K at a locked 60fps, or around 65fps with VRR. Very slightly more blurry than favor resolution pro mode (particularly SSR) due to lower base resolution before upscaling, but looks less aliased in motion.

extraInfo: All 3 modes have improved shadows, depth-of-field, skin/hair shaders, clouds, god rays etc compared to base PS5, and these improvements are even more noticeable in motion. Base PS5 also has DRS that hits max 1800p checkerboarding in performance mode, which looks far blurrier (especially foliage and SSR in bodies of water) and more aliased/unstable than Pro performance mode. Pro performance mode even beats base PS5 resolution mode except for slightly blurrier SSR. Digital Foundry thinks it's the best looking console game (along with Horizon Forbidden West) ever! Equivalent to a high-end PC game and even beats DLSS in places like SSR.

name: Horizon 2 Forbidden West

modes.name: favor resolution pro
modes.description: 1584p-4K native DRS at a locked 30fps.

modes.name: balanced pro
modes.description: Looks almost identical to favor performance pro mode, but is capped at 40fps.

modes.name: favor performance pro
modes.description: 1440p-1584p DRS to 4K at a locked 60fps, or around 65fps with VRR. Very slightly more blurry than favor resolution pro mode (particularly SSR) due to lower base resolution before upscaling, but looks less aliased in motion.

extraInfo: All 3 modes have improved shadows, depth-of-field, skin/hair shaders, clouds, god rays etc compared to base PS5, and these improvements are even more noticeable in motion. Base PS5 also has DRS that hits max 1800p checkerboarding in performance mode, which looks far blurrier (especially foliage and SSR in bodies of water) and more aliased/unstable than Pro performance mode. Pro performance mode even beats base PS5 resolution mode except for slightly blurrier SSR. Digital Foundry thinks it's the best looking console game (along with Horizon Zero Dawn) ever! Equivalent to a high-end PC game and even beats DLSS in places like SSR.

name: Hunt: Showdown 1896
extraInfo: According to Crytek, Pro has 'increased graphical settings' compared to base PS5 and Pro's 60fps is more stable. PSSR also creates a sharper image than the 1260p to 4K FSR2 on base PS5. However, Pro's PSSR implementation results in a lot more shimmering/flickering than FSR2. To the point that many feel Pro's image looks worse despite the sharper render. There's also anecdotal comments throughout the community that Pro crashes more often.

name: Hypercharge: Unboxed
extraInfo: Digital Cybercherries has confirmed that a PS5 Pro patch is in development, though no timeline or specific enhancements have been announced. Given that Hypercharge already runs at native 4K and is primarily a multiplayer-focused title, the most logical upgrade would be the addition of a 120fps mode. Ray tracing reflections could also meaningfully enhance the game's visuals, especially in the campaign, thanks to its cartoon/toy-like aesthetic. However, 120fps support would likely remain the priority as most players engage with the game through PvP.

name: Indiana Jones: GC
pageTitle: Indiana Jones And The Great Circle
extraInfo: Pro's dynamic resolution scale ranges from 1440p to native 4K, which it regularly hits. Base PS5's DRS only renders up to 1800p and dips as low as 1200p. Both consoles have a very stable 60fps framerate, but Pro hits 60fps slightly more often. Even with its slightly improved RTGI and ambient occlusion/shadows implementation. There's no option to unlock the framerate, even though Pro looks like it has the headroom for a noticeable increase past 60fps. Cutscenes are locked to 60fps everywhere (even PC).

name: Karma: The Dark World
extraInfo: The developers claim Pro is native 4K, but also using PSSR in order to get a 'rock solid' 60fps. Pro also has enhanced texture streaming and volumetric effects, higher quality texture filtering, improved distance rendering, and better temporal stability compared to base PS5.

name: Kayak VR: Mirage
extraInfo: Pro has 8K textures compared to 4K on base PS5. Pro also has improved post-processing, effects, LOD distance and anti-aliasing. Both consoles have dynamic resolution scaling, but Pro only hits a low of 90% of 4K, whereas base PS5 can only render between 60%-90% of 4K.

name: Killing Floor 3
extraInfo: While Pro utilizes UE5's TSR to target an upscaled 1800p, base PS5 only targets 1440p. These outputs are however dynamic, but at least Pro targets a noticeably higher ceiling. The framerate does dip below 60fps on both Pro and base PS5, but should stay within the VRR window for most of the instances it does dip.

name: Kingdom Come: Deliverance 2
extraInfo: Pro is 1296p-1440p DRS to 4K PSSR at a nearly locked 60fps, or around 70fps (highs of 90s) with VRR on. Base PS5 is only 1080p to 1440p FSR at 60fps, though 1440p to 4K FSR at 30fps. Even though Pro can have a lower base resolution before upscaling, PSSR still produces the clearest (albeit a little noisier) image. Pro also has the same improved tree/shadow LODs, ambient occlusion and object quality of base PS5's fidelity mode, but at 60fps, making Pro's mode the best of both worlds.

name: Lies Of P

modes.name: quality-centered
modes.description: 4K at 30fps, or 40fps+ if HFR (VRR) is activated. Higher quality shadows, textures, SSR and volumetric fog than performance-centered mode.

modes.name: performance-centered
modes.description: 4K at a basically locked 60fps. HFR is disabled in this mode.

extraInfo: Pro performance-centered mode is a native 4K, whereas base PS5 performance-centered mode has DRS that internally renders between 1512p-1800p, before upscaling to 4K. Pro quality-centered mode also has at least a 30% increase in FPS (with VRR enabled) compared to base PS5 quality-centered mode's 30fps.

name: Like A Dragon: Pirate Yakuza In Hawaii
pageTitle: Like A Dragon: Pirate Yakuza In Hawaii
extraInfo: While both Pro and base PS5 run at 60fps, Pro's framerate is basically locked at 60fps whereas base PS5 can dip below more often. Base PS5's lower 1080p internal resolution (compared to Pro's 1440p) also results in noticeably more fizzle in assets like hair.

name: Lords Of The Fallen

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 4K at a locked 30fps with Lumen GI.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1440p to 4K via a custom version of UE5's upscaling at 60fps plus Lumen.

extraInfo: Hexworks states that Pro has a 40% increase in pixels compared to base PS5, resulting in sharper distant details and more refined textures on characters/environments. In practice, this increase can be even larger as base PS5 performance mode is between 648p-1152p DRS and quality mode is 1296p-1620p DRS. Pro also hits its target framerate more often than base PS5 in both modes and is equivalent to the highest PC graphical settings.

name: Lost Soul Aside
rtTypes: Ray traced lighting, shadows and reflections (likely)
extraInfo: LSA ships in August, but based off Yang Bing's (LSA creator) comments, we can make educated assumptions on a few things. Firstly, Bing has stated that Pro will run at a higher resolution and more stable framerate than base PS5. Bing is also receiving significant aid from Sony's China Hero Project, who convinced him to stick with the less resource-intensive Unreal Engine 4. The PlayStation official page also hints to RT lighting, shadows and reflections, with PC specs already confirming its happening there. All this suggests there's a good chance Pro will be able to come close to the visual triangle of 4K, 60fps and RT. Perhaps using PSSR (unconfirmed) to achieve this.

name: Madden NFL 25
extraInfo: Removes the resolution, performance and visual quality modes seen in base PS5 for just one Pro mode. PSSR renders a sharper image than even base PS5 resolution mode (especially grass, which is now 3D during gameplay in more zoomed in cameras), but it causes certain assets like crowd handrails to be more shimmery/unstable. All cutscenes/instant replays are now also 60fps like in base PS5 performance mode and gameplay is a locked 60fps.

name: Madden NFL 26
extraInfo: *Madden 26 isn't out yet, but the following Madden 25 information from last year should give us at least a good baseline of what to expect. Especially as this is the first current-gen Madden to not release on PS4 - 'Removes the resolution, performance and visual quality modes seen in base PS5 for just one Pro mode. PSSR renders a sharper image than even base PS5 resolution mode (especially grass, which is now 3D during gameplay in more zoomed in cameras), but it causes certain assets like crowd handrails to be more shimmery/unstable. All cutscenes/instant replays are now also 60fps like in base PS5 performance mode and gameplay is a locked 60fps.'

name: Mafia: The Old Country
extraInfo: Hangar 13 have confirmed that base PS5 will include both a 30fps quality mode and 60fps performance mode at launch. It's therefore likely that Pro has the same modes, but with a higher internal resolution before applying UE5's TSR to upscale to a 4K resolution. Additionally, Hangar 13 have also released their PC specifications and didn't discuss any form of RT. This means it's unlikely that there will be any form of UE5's RT on consoles, but this is just an educated guess. We won't have hard details on potential RT implementation/resolutions until closer to launch.

name: Mandragora: WOTWT
pageTitle: Mandragora: Whispers of the Witch Tree

modes.name: quality pro
modes.description: 4K native at a stable 60fps.

modes.name: performance pro
modes.description: 1440p native that targets 120fps.

extraInfo: Base PS5 only has one mode that runs at 1800p/60fps. While this is just slightly worse than Pro's 4K/60fps quality mode, it means that Pro has an exclusive 120fps mode for gamers who prefer to maximize the framerate.

name: Marathon
extraInfo: So far, the only technical information Bungie has disclosed is that Marathon will utilize PSSR on Pro. However, both 120fps and/or a 4K final render are likely. These educated assumptions are based off Marathon's focus on art style over resource-intensive realism, as well as their previous game (Destiny 2) already achieving these metrics on a base PS5, as the game isn't Pro enhanced.

name: Marvel Rivals
rtTypes: Unreal Engine 5 Lumen global illumination and reflections

modes.name: pro
modes.description: 1440p to 4K PSSR at a locked 60fps, with Lumen Reflections & GI.

modes.name: HFR
modes.description: 1440p at a nearly locked 120fps.

extraInfo: Base PS5 only has Lumen GI in its quality mode, whereas Pro also has Lumen Reflections. Pro's PSSR implementation renders a sharper image than possible on base PS5, but is also a bit noisier/unstable. Pro also not only hits 120fps in its HFR mode much more often than base PS5, which regularly dips to around 110fps, but does so at a higher resolution too.

name: Metal Gear Solid Delta: SE
extraInfo: Konami has confirmed that there will be both a quality and performance mode on Pro. They've also confirmed that Pro will use PSSR, but didn't mention if it's just for performance mode or for both. RT is currently labelled as false, but based off the PC requirements (minimum specs require at least a 2060 Super GPU), it's very possible that Pro could utilize RT, at least in quality mode. Likely Unreal Engine 5's Lumen and hopefully the superior hardware-based version, but this is all speculation.

name: Midnight Murder Club
extraInfo: Both Pro and base PS5 run at 4K. Instead, Pro surpasses the base PS5 version by its ability to maintain a locked 60fps, regardless of what VFX Quality setting is chosen. There is very low, low, medium, high and best, and it's at these higher options where base PS5 can dip below 60fps. Especially if the FOV is also on a wider setting. Pro will however remain a locked 60fps even if both are maxed out.

name: MindsEye
extraInfo: MindsEye is one of very few Pro games that lacks a 60fps mode. However, it also struggles to maintain a stable, properly paced 30fps - regularly dipping into the low 20s in various open-world and combat scenarios, with lots of screen tearing (base PS5 performs even worse as it drops to under 20fps). Pro also has slightly improved textures, terrain detail and shadows over base PS5, but its upscaled 4K output still looks very blurry when at its lowest internal resolution. Image stability is however still much better on Pro compared to base PS5, which can internally render below 720p. At the very least, cutscene quality on both consoles looks much better than gameplay.

name: Monster Hunter Wilds

modes.name: prioritize resolution
modes.description: 1728p-1944p DRS to 4K PSSR with RT reflections. Nearly locked 30fps, or up to 45fps with VRR.

modes.name: balanced
modes.description: 1404p to 4K PSSR with very slightly worse RT than prioritize resolution mode. Nearly locked 40fps, or low 40s in VRR.

modes.name: prioritize framerate
modes.description: 1080p to 4K PSSR with RT disabled. Nearly locked 60fps, or up to 80fps with VRR. Worse GI, lighting and LODs than other modes.

extraInfo: RT reflections look significantly better than SSR due to no occlusion issues. Pro's PSSR looks much better than base PS5's FSR1 as the image (though slightly softer) has a lot less aliasing/breakup and more temporal stability. This contrast is widened as internal resolution lowers to as low as 720p on base PS5. Pro prioritize framerate mode also hits 60fps more often than the base PS5 version. There's no LFC, so VRR isn't recommended in resolution/balanced modes that rarely reach above 60fps anyways.

name: Mortal Kombat 1
extraInfo: The only big difference between Pro and base PS5 is how reflections are rendered. Pro uses RT, whereas base PS5 uses less accurate SSR (screen space reflections). Pro still has dynamic resolution scaling that can go as low as 1800p, but renders at native 4K more often than base PS5. Finally, both consoles run at a basically locked 60fps.

name: My First Gran Turismo

modes.name: 8K 60 Hz
modes.description: 4K to 8K PSSR at a locked 60fps, but with no RT. Requires PSSR to upscale.

modes.name: prioritize ray-tracing/resolution
modes.description: 4K PSSR/TAA at a locked 60fps with RT reflections.

modes.name: prioritize framerate
modes.description: 1800p to 4K PSSR/TAA at a locked 120fps with no RT.

extraInfo: *MFTG is a free, beginner-friendly introduction to the world of GT. Basically, an expanded demo with a limited number of cars/racetracks. However, its tech details remain the same as the premium GT7 product - 'Unlike base PS5, RT reflections are now available during gameplay. Its excellent implementation is far superior to the cube maps used when RT is disabled. Both TAA and PSSR are available for upscaling and both support RT except for cockpit mode, which is only PSSR. PSSR still looks great, but can can produce additional shimmer/noise in thin objects and artifacting on a few cars compared to TAA. All framerates are locked 99% of the time in gameplay, but replays can drop the framerate more often. Finally, Pro significantly improves motion clarity and image quality in its optional PSVR2 mode.'

name: Naraka: Bladepoint

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 4K at 60fps. According to 24 Entertainment - 'ideal for users seeking better visual experiences'.

modes.name: balanced
modes.description: 1080p (likely) to 4K PSSR, with either a 60fps or 120fps cap - 'balancing both visual quality and smoothness'.

modes.name: high frames
modes.description: Native 1080p at 60fps, 120fps, 240fps, or 'unlimited' fps (check extra info) - 'for users who need the highest frame rates, ensuring smoother gameplay'.

extraInfo: 60fps at native 4K isn't possible on base PS5. Although high frames mode has toggles for 240fps and unlimited fps, Pro isn't capable of running above 120fps. So in practice, high frames mode has the same 60/120fps cap toggles as balanced mode. It'll just maintain the target framerate more often due to the lower resolution.

name: NBA 2K25
extraInfo: The biggest difference between Pro and base PS5 is the addition of RT reflections in The City. Pro also uses PSSR to upscale from 1440p (likely) to 4K. This creates a slightly sharper image compared to base PS5, however PSSR also causes certain assets like handrails in the stands to render a bit more unstable.

name: NBA 2K26
extraInfo: *NBA 2K26 isn't out yet, but the following information from last year's NBA 2K25 provides a good baseline of what to expect - 'The biggest difference between Pro and base PS5 is the addition of RT reflections in The City. Pro also uses PSSR to upscale from 1440p (likely) to 4K. This creates a slightly sharper image compared to base PS5, however PSSR also causes certain assets like handrails in the stands to render a bit more unstable.'

name: Nioh 3
extraInfo: When Nioh 1 & 2 came to PS5, they had a 4K/60fps mode, a 1080p DRS/60fps mode (with higher graphical settings like shadows) and a reduced fidelity 120fps mode. However, Nioh 3's June 2025 demo didn't support 120fps on either Pro or base PS5. Additionally, Nioh 3 was unable to maintain a stable 60fps or a consistent 1080p+ resolution in either its prioritize framerate or prioritize graphics modes on both consoles, though the Pro performed better on average. That said, this was just a demo, so these issues will likely improve by Nioh 3's launch. Unfortunately, given Nioh 3's current-gen only, and now open-world design, hitting 120fps may not be feasible without unacceptable resolution tradeoffs. Hopefully, this also changes with improved optimization before the early 2026 release.

name: Ninja Gaiden 2 Black
rtTypes: Unreal Engine 5 software-based Lumen reflections and global illumination

modes.name: fidelity
modes.description: Upscaled 4K TSR at locked 60fps except for some cutscenes (lows of mid 50s).

modes.name: performance
modes.description: Upscaled 1080p TSR at somewhat stable 120fps depending on level (lows of 90s). Less detailed shadows/non-Nanite geometry.

extraInfo: There's no actual modes. Instead, you switch between the 2 framerate targets via the FPS limit toggle's 60fps and 120fps values. Both modes use Lumen combined with SSR for reflections and Lumen GI for indirect lighting. Base PS5 has the same 2 modes, however, Pro has a higher base resolution before upscaling and hits its target framerate more often.

name: No Man's Sky

modes.name: 8K resolution
modes.description: 2592-2700p DRS to 8K PSSR at a locked 30fps.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 4K PSSR at a basically locked 60fps.

extraInfo: Both modes also have improved lighting, ultra quality reflections and higher quality ambient occlusion compared to base PS5. These improvements are also seen in the PSVR2 version. PSSR implementation works very well due to the high base resolution.

name: Off The Grid

modes.name: fidelity
modes.description: 4K FSR3/TSR/PSSR at usually around 65fps with VRR.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1080p FSR3/TSR/PSSR at usually around 85fps with VRR.

extraInfo: Pro can choose between FSR3, TSR or PSSR for upscaling. All 3 run at a similar fps (give or take 5-10fps) and can be capped at 30/40/60fps. However, while FSR3 and TSR (a bit more stable than FSR3) render a good image, PSSR results in shimmering/flickering, as well as strobing in assets like foliage. Similar to SW Jedi: Survivor when Pro first launched. Fidelity mode renders a 4K-looking image and is 99% locked above the 48fps VRR window. Performance mode has a roughly 20fps increase and even hits 120fps, but the 1080p-like image is much blurrier regardless of upscaler. Finally, OTG is in early access so this tech analysis is likely to change when 1.0 launches.

name: Oppidum
extraInfo: Pro is a native 4K at 60fps. This combines the best of base PS5's performance (1440p/60fps) and quality (4K/30fps) modes.

name: Outbreak: SOHCS
pageTitle: Outbreak: Shades of Horror Chromatic Split
extraInfo: Uses PSSR to hit 4K (base resolution unknown, but almost certainly above 1080p due to final output). Pro also has significantly enhanced RT, texture resolution, other visual effects etc compared to base PS5, and hits 60fps more often.

name: Paladin's Passage

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 8K PSSR at 30fps.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 4K at 60fps.

extraInfo: According to the game's website, 'advanced shaders' are now on Pro. PSSR is also used to render up to 8K.

name: Path Of Exile 2

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 1662p NIS or PSSR 'quality' to 4K with DRS, at a locked 60fps.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1440p NIS or PSSR 'balanced' to 4K without DRS, at a relatively stable 120fps.

extraInfo: With 4 upscalers that each have multiple quality options within them, a sharpness slider, different lighting toggles, multiple refresh rate options (including 30/40fps), and even experimental options like dynamic culling, PoE2 easily has the most configurations of a PS5 Pro game. Instead of listing 50+ modes, the 2 above represent what the general PoE2 community recommend depending on your framerate target. Performance mode can dip in heavy fights, but should stay above 60fps most of the time. NIS is sharper and more performant that PSSR, but less stable in motion and can look too sharp. Though PSSR's softness results in a loss of texture detail. If you want to maximize frames, ensure lighting is set to just 'shadows' instead of  'shadows + GI'. Dynamic culling is also not recommended as it can cause severe graphical issues.

name: Pathfinder: WOTR

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 4K at a mostly stable 60fps.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1080p at a locked 60fps.

extraInfo: Quality mode can dip below 60fps, but it's not common. It also only dips to the low 50s, which is well within the VRR window. Performance mode is a locked 60fps, but at 1080p, it's noticeably blurrier than quality mode's 4K. Base PS5 only has one mode which renders at 4K, but with a far more unstable 60fps that regularly falls below the VRR window (usually 35-45fps).

name: Phantom Blade Zero
extraInfo: S-Game have stated that Pro will have enhanced visuals over base PS5, which is targeting a 1440p/60fps mode and a 4K/30fps mode. However, in their Feb 2025 comments to Vice, this base PS5 performance mode can drop to as low as 40fps right now. Between their Pro comments and current base PS5 performance, it's unlikely that Pro will support 120fps. Potentially, the Pro performance mode will have 'enhanced visuals' with a resolution above 1440p and a more stable 60fps. S-Game have also stated that AMD have provided hardware-base RT solutions for PS5, so perhaps a Pro quality mode will support RT in a way that base PS5 can't. This is just conjecture though and we don't know if PBZ will end up with RT at all. We will find out closer to its 2026 launch.

name: Pure Pool Pro

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 8K native at 60fps.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 4K at 120fps.

extraInfo: Ripstone's Reddit/Steam account confirmed that the above modes is what Pro will be targeting. This will be Pro's first and (currently) only game to run at native 8K.

name: Quantum Error
rtTypes: Ray traced reflections, global illumination and shadows (base PS5)
extraInfo: While TeamKill confirmed they're working on a PS5 Pro update as early as October 2024, this has yet to come to fruition (the above tech info is taken from the base PS5 version). The last time they discussed this update was in May and they currently seem to be focused on their upcoming game 'Code Violet', which launches in November 2025. Hopefully when that game releases, TeamKill will have the bandwidth to make good on their promise of Pro support for Quantum Error.

name: Quisisana
extraInfo: Pro renders at 4K/60fps. However, there's (seemingly) no aliasing solution implemented, so edges of assets like doors/windows etc are still very jagged. Graphical settings such as lighting and some shadows are improved over Domynyo's previous game (Sanguis Luna). However, the differences in these graphical settings between the base PS5 and Pro version seem minimal.

name: Ratchet & Clank: Rift Apart
rtTypes: Ray traced reflections and ambient occlusion

modes.name: fidelity pro
modes.description: 4K PSSR at a locked 30fps/40fps for 60 Hz/120 Hz screens, or nearly 60fps with VRR. Highest quality RT (explained below).

modes.name: performance pro
modes.description: 1584p to 4K PSSR at a locked 60fps, or around 80-90fps with VRR.

extraInfo: Fidelity Pro is sharper/more stable than Performance Pro, but PSSR in general resolves more detail than the FSR upscaling utilized in every base PS5 mode. Especially in motion with less aliasing etc, but PSSR can be noisier in stills. Performance Pro mode has much sharper RT reflections than base PS5 Performance RT mode. Fidelity Pro RT reflections look even less aliased as they're full resolution and its RTAO has more contact shadows - adding depth to assets all over the screen.

name: Ready Or Not

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 1440p-1552p DRS to 4K native at an unevenly paced 30fps.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1350p-1440p DRS to 4K at a nearly locked 60fps.

extraInfo: VOID stated in a pre-launch interview that Ready or Not uses PSSR in the Pro version. However, it's very unlikely that it's currently Pro enhanced. For one, it doesn't have the Pro enhanced confirmation on the PSN store. It also uses similar DRS bounds compared to the same mode on base PS5. The Series X fares even worse, with downgraded  graphical settings/resolution compared to base PS5. Fortunately, VOID have acknowledged these issues and said this will be fixed in a future patch, which hopefully also comes with proper Pro enhancements. At the very least right now, Pro helps Ready or Not maintain its 60fps more often. Although the unevenly paced 30ps in quality mode results in a sub-optimal experience on both PS5 consoles.

name: Redacted

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 8K at a locked 60fps with supersampling.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 4K at a locked 120fps.

extraInfo: Base PS5 doesn't have an 8K mode. It also can't run at 120fps when rendering at 4K. You can choose Pro's quality mode on a non-8K screen, but the game makes it clear that the game will be down-sampled to the resolution of your screen and therefore make this choice pointless.

name: Resident Evil 4

modes.name: resolution
modes.description: Native 4K at a locked 60fps with RT/better hair quality. Can also toggle HFR on which then increases the framerate to 70-90fps.

modes.name: high frame rate
modes.description: 864p to 4K PSSR without RT/better hair quality. 85-105fps usually, but can be a locked 120fps in interiors.

extraInfo: There's a lot of toggles in this game for RT/HFR/better hair quality etc, so the 2 modes above represent the image quality with all the toggles either on or off. Resolution mode holds a much more stable 60fps than same mode on base PS5, which hovers around 45fps.

name: Resident Evil Village
rtTypes: Ray traced global illumination, ambient occlusion and reflections

modes.name: ray tracing
modes.description: 864p to 4K PSSR at a locked 60fps with RT.

modes.name: high frame rate
modes.description: 864p to 4K PSSR at a locked 120fps with no RT.

extraInfo: You can actually toggle both RT and HFR on, with the framerate then ranging from from 65fps-90fps. 120fps is not on base PS5, which uses 4K checkerboard rendering (1920x2160) and even then, still can't hold a stable 60fps with RT enabled. PSSR is less sharp compared to base PS5's CBR, but also less noisy, with less artifacting on moving objects like tree branches.

name: Resist
extraInfo: There is only one difference between Pro and base PS5. Pro runs at 120 Hz whereas base PS5 runs at 90 Hz.

name: Retrieval
extraInfo: The Pro version will have more detailed environments, higher quality RT reflections and a sharper resolution compared to the base PS5 version. All at a more stable 60fps.

name: Returnal
extraInfo: Pro has roughly 2.5x the resolution compared to base PS5, resulting in a very frequent internal resolution of 1728p max (infrequent DRS of 1350p min) that outputs to 4K (base PS5 is a fixed 1080p that reconstructs to 1440p before upscaling to a 4K checkerboard). This leads to a less noisy/grainy image with less aliasing/flickering, though some image instability remains. Both PS5 consoles have framerate dips into the low 50s, but this occurs less often on Pro. Technically, Returnal uses other forms of RT outside of audio. However, this is only for background calculations, not for visual improvements, so it's not listed.

name: Rise Of The Ronin

modes.name: prioritize graphics + ray tracing
modes.description: 1440p to 4K PSSR with RT reflections at a very unstable 60fps (usually around 45fps in actual gameplay).

modes.name: prioritize graphics
modes.description: 1440p to 4K PSSR. Slightly higher average framerate than prioritize graphics + RT mode.

modes.name: prioritize FPS
modes.description: 1070p-1440p DRS to 4K PSSR at a nearly locked 60fps with no RT.

extraInfo: Both graphics modes' framerate fall far below the VRR limit for a majority of gameplay. You can cap the framerate to 30fps, but it has uneven frame pacing so these modes will feel choppy regardless of your setup. The superior RT reflections make little difference in this scenario because of the framerate issue. Prioritize FPS mode however runs great, and even with the lower bound of its dynamic resolution scaling, Pro's PSSR renders a more clear/less aliased image than base PS5's FSR (even in its graphics modes). Especially with foliage which regularly fills the screen.

name: RoadCraft

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 1080p-4K native DRS to 4K FSR3 at 30fps.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1080p-1440p DRS to 4K FSR3 at 60fps.

extraInfo: Base PS5 also uses dynamic resolution scaling. However, its lowest internal resolution is 720p in base PS5 performance mode and it can only reach up to 1440p in its quality mode. Pro is therefore much sharper as its rendering 2x the pixels when both PS5 consoles max out their resolution, but this is the only difference between them.

name: Rogue Flight

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 8K at a very stable 60fps.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 4K at a very stable 120fps.

extraInfo: According to Truant Pixel, outside of resolution/framerate increases compared to the same modes on base PS5, Pro also has 'additional small graphical touches'.

name: Sanguis Luna
extraInfo: Pro renders at 4K/60fps. However, there's (seemingly) no aliasing solution implemented, so edges of assets like doors/windows etc are still very jagged. Other graphical settings are also mediocre, such as missing shadows on basic assets like books. Therefore, the impact of any potential upgrades from base PS5 to Pro is minimal.

name: Shredders
extraInfo: Base PS5 and Pro both achieve a nearly locked 60fps. However, Pro runs at 4K native compared to base PS5's 1440p, which is a 2x resolution increase.

name: Silent Hill 2
rtTypes: Hardware-based ray traced reflections and global illumination

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 1080p to 4K PSSR at a locked 30fps with hardware-based RT.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 900p-1152p DRS to 4K TSR. Somewhat stable 60fps (lows of high 40s) with hardware-based RT.

extraInfo: Pro uses superior hardware-based RT compared to software-based RT on base PS5 (less breakup/clearer reflections etc) and both modes hit target framerate more often than their base PS5 version. Pro's performance mode also has a higher base resolution. However, Pro's quality mode, despite a more 4K like image and better RT, has so much PSSR shimmer that base PS5 quality mode looks better with TSR. Fortunately, Bloober has confirmed that they're working with Konami on a patch, which will hopefully improve the PSSR implementation or revert to TSR (as they did for performance).

name: Silent Hill F
extraInfo: Digital Foundry has confirmed that the June 2025 State of Play trailer (captured on PS5 Pro) used UE5's software-based Lumen for RT. While cutscenes ran at 30fps, gameplay maintained a stable 60fps, which likely explains the decision to not use more advanced hardware-based RT. It's possible that hardware-based RT could improve the visual fidelity of Pro's 30fps quality mode, but this is purely speculative.

name: Skull And Bones
extraInfo: Pro combines elements of base PS5 quality mode (4K native with RTGI at 30fps) and performance mode (720p fixed to 1440p FSR2 at 60fps) into one mode (Approx 1440p at 60fps with RTGI). In practice, Pro's framerate is not a locked 60fps on either land or sea, but only dips to 55fps-58fps which is well within the VRR window. The resolution is a clear improvement over base PS5 performance mode, but reflections remain noticeably low-res. Since screen space reflections dominate the ocean surfaces, the overall visual quality still falls short of Pro expectations. Finally, the RTGI implementation is identical to the base PS5 quality mode - limited to the player's ship.

name: Slitterhead
extraInfo: A native 4K and more stable 60fps compared to base PS5, especially in later boss fights. *Technical information is aggregated off anecdotal remarks by gamers who have completed Slitterhead, not from a primary source or established secondary source like Digital Foundry as none exist at time of writing.

name: Smash Drums

modes.name: fidelity
modes.description: 120fps with higher resolution and better VFX compared to performance mode.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 120fps native.

extraInfo: Whereas base PS5 is only 90fps in its fidelity mode and 120fps performance mode, Pro is 120fps in both.

name: Sniper Elite: Resistance
extraInfo: Both PS5 consoles have dynamic resolution scaling, but Pro hits native 4K often, which is extremely rare on base PS5. Base PS5 also renders a low of 1296p often when that's less than 1% on Pro. However, all versions (Xbox/PC too) are poorly aliased, so resolution gaps are less noticeable than in other games because there's so much shimmer regardless. Pro's 60fps is locked aside from some effect-heavy explosions. This is more stable than base PS5, which can drop to low 50s in general gameplay.

name: Spider-Man 1 Remastered
rtTypes: Ray traced reflections, shadows and ambient occlusion

modes.name: fidelity
modes.description: Legacy base PS5 fidelity mode (all RT/more asset density etc). 4K at locked 30fps/40fps for 60 Hz/120 Hz screens.

modes.name: performance pro
modes.description: 1440p to 4K PSSR at a locked 60fps, or usually around 75-90fps with VRR. Fidelity mode level of image quality (RT/increased pedestrian density etc).
